Award.AwardTitle: Strings, Branes, and Higher Spin Theories
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Katrin Becker, Melanie Becker, and Ergin Sezgin at Texas A&M University.

String theory requires gravity and extends the standard model of particle physics and grand unified theories. Its mathematical consistency requires more than the four spacetime dimensions, and the ways in which the extra dimensions are dealth with in turn determines the observed particles and forces. Therefore, it is important to understand the imprints left by the geometry and topology of the extra dimensions on the observed four-dimensional spacetime. The PI's will explore fundamental aspects of string theory and supergravity as they relate to these issues. As such, this project advances the national interest by promoting progress in science and the search for new physical laws describing uncharted territories of quantum gravity. This project is also envisioned to have broader impact by boosting the interfaces between string theory and mathematics. The PIs will also provide critical training to postdocs and students, and intend to give public lectures on their research results and organize workshops.

More technically, the PIs aim to construct the full spacetime effective action of different string theory and M-theory compactifications to all orders in the slope parameter and its formulation in superspace. Their goal is to use physics to solve long-standing problems in mathematics (e.g,. the search of a "Calabi-Yau-type" theorem for manifolds with exceptional holonomy or to search for an analogue of mirror symmetry). Further, the PI's will study the construction of an action principle for higher-spin theory, its quantization, higher-spin invariant functionals, and higher-spin black holes. They will also study supersymmetric field theories in curved backgrounds, superconformal field theories in diverse dimensions, and a geometrical description of duality symmetries of strings and branes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was used to support three principal investigators and their group of postdoctoral fellows, graduate students and visitors. Their research projects deal with  fundamental aspects of string theory and M-theory and their implications for particle physics and mathematics.

E. Sezgin: Two areas in which our research has focused on are higher spin gravities and exceptional field theories. Higher spin gravities provide an extension of Einstein's theory of gravity to include an infinite tower of massless higher spin fields. It is well motivated not only for being expected to arise in the tensionless limit of string theory, but it also holds remarkable prospects of possibly being a consistent theory of quantum gravity by itself, thanks to the vast amount of symmetries it has. We have investigated the holography by which the physics of higher spin gravity is encoded in a remarkably simple field theory that resides on the boundary of spacetime. We have carried out rare quantum loop effect computations that are relevant for refining the testing of this phenomenon. We have also found cosmological solutions of the theory which may have impact on the physics of early universe, where ultra high energies are present. Such an era is a natural for exploring higher spin gravity, and indeed it may have consequences for the cosmological microwave background, albeit very small, and yet possibly observable in the future. On the mathematical side, we have found that the description of higher spin gravity has drastically different properties compared to Einstein’s theory of gravity, and it requires new mathematical tools. We have initiated the process of building some of those tools, which involve special kinds of  noncommutative gauge field theories.

 Exceptional field theories, which is the second main area which our work has focused on, provide a powerful framework for probing the hidden symmetries of supergravity theories, which, in turn, are the low energy effective field theory limits of string theory.  These theories introduce a generalized geometry fo spacetime in which extra dimensions of special kind are introduced, and make the hidden symmetries manifest. This framework unifies several supergravities in diverse dimensions, makes their duality symmetries manifest, and facilitates the derivation of results in higher dimensional supergravity theories which were forbiddingly difficult to obtain in the past. We have focused especially on the exceptional field theory known as E11 theory from which, ultimately all others should be derivable in the future. A challenging problem is the fully nonlinear formulation of its field equations. We have made a major progress toward that goal over the last year.

K. Becker and M. Becker: Our efforts have been focused on rewriting eleven-dimensional supergravity in four-dimensional N=1 superspace. Eleven-dimensional supergravity is the low-energy limit of M-theory, a theory that many believe is our most promising candidate to be a theory of quantum gravity. It is then desirable to find a formulation of eleven-dimensional supergravity with manifest symmetries (we focus on N=1 supersymmetry in four dimensions). Such a formulation might hold clues on how the theory behaves beyond the supergravity approximation (where it becomes a theory of quantum gravity). Such a formulation is also user friendly when it comes to application to particle physics or condensed matter physics. 

We first identified the structure of the N=1 tensor hierarchy that descend from the M-theory 3-form. We constructed the unique N=1 Chern-Simons action. The superfields in this hierarchy encode all fields with spin less or equal to one. The N=1 Chern-Simons action combined with a natural choice of Kaehler potential led to a scalar potential that precisely reproduces the internal sector of the eleven-dimensional action. Most kinetic terms were also correctly reproduced except certain fields in the 7 representation of G_2. To correctly obtain all kinetic terms additional superfields, namely gravitino superfields had to be taken into account. We coupled the non-abelian tensor hierarchy to a set of gravitino superfields. Then we coupled this action to supergravity. When the superspace action is projected to components, we recover the full linearized action of eleven-dimensional supergravity.
Understanding how M-theory behaves beyond the supergravity approximation is clearly challenging. The construction of the M-theory action with manifest supersymmetries will be useful to understand these corrections. We also developed new techniques to calculate scattering amplitudes as well as M-theory actions. We expect the results on scattering amplitudes together with the non-renormalization theorems to determine corrections to eleven-dimensional supergravity. These corrections encode the difference between gravity and quantum gravity.
